It's hard to think of a dumber idea than landing people on Mars. Robots and rovers could explore the planet far more safely, cheaper and more effectively than humans could. Even with robots, it's about a 50-50% chance of landing safely. Would it be ethical to send humans on a mission in which they have a 50% chance of crashing?  Also, we don't currently have a technology to take off from the planet (assuming we could land safely). Keeping the astronauts alive on the surface would likely be impossible given how harsh conditions are there. It would be a colossal waste of money.

Made no mention of the biggest challenge of all, The length of time the astronauts would be exposed to radiation.  Estimates are that humans unshielded in interplanetary space would receive annually roughly 400 to 900 mSv (compared to 2.4 mSv on Earth) and that a Mars mission (12 months in flight and 18 months on Mars) might expose shielded astronauts to roughly 500 to 1000 mSv. So they have to be shielded which is a huge problem weight wise.

UAE MARS PROBE ENTERS ORBIT
IN FIRST ARAB MISSION

The UAE's first mission to Mars reached the red planet and inserted itself into it's orbit on Tuesday following a seventh month journey.

This makes the UAE the fifth space agency to reach the planet in what is the first Arab interplanetary probe.

The Mars programme called ' Amal '
(Hope) is part of the UAE's efforts to develop its tech capabilities and reduce its reliance on oil.

I get a bit annoyed hearing that Mars is a graveyard for failed spacecraft landings over and over again.  Sure there were lots of early failures, but we have been learning along the way.  Aggregating the old failures with the more successful recent ones and implying the average is what we can expect in the future paints a quite misleading and unnecessarily grim picture.  The truth is this is still a fantastically difficult thing to do, but humanity is getting better at it.
